ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I mostly learned about the different approaches to documentary filmmaking and the ethical concerns involved. I also learned how to use premiere pro a bit for the final project.

I learned the basics of documentary filmmaking. The course culminated in making an 8-12 minute documentary on a topic of our choosing. It was really valuable to me to learn how to use Premiere Pro (the video editing software) and to think about crafting a story with a beginning, middle, and end. Besides the actual filmmaking process, we also watched lots of documentaries and discussed issues of social justice in class.

I received an overview of the history and methods of documentary filmmaking, learned how to use editing software Premiere Pro, did a workshop on interviewing, and learned techniques to shoot and edit a short documentary. The class also engaged in thoughtful discussions about how documentary film can be  a mechanism for social change and the ethics of nonfiction storytelling.
Learned the fundamentals of documentary filmmaking, got exposed to guest documentarians and artists, discussed theoretical aspects of documentary such as distribution and impact

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Professor Steiner and Mickey (TA) were wonderful, so that was definitely a strength. Since it was once a week, it felt like a pretty chill class overall which I enjoyed, especially given the online environment. 
I think one weakness is that we weren't really instructed on certain techniques to work on, so if you're looking for a class that really walks you through filming techniques, you might not like it that much. The teaching style was very much just go out and shoot something and experiment with things for yourself. This style was fun though, and a lot of the learning came from seeing what your classmates did.

Strengths - We had a wonderful, welcoming class environment. People gave great feedback on everyone's work. I think the class was really well-structured to help us plan and make our documentaries. We had several assignments and deadlines leading up to the final that helped us plan our work. I also appreciated the chance to watch a lot of films covering different issues. Steiner is a huge strength of this class- she's really helpful and passionate about working with students. Also the workload is very manageable with Steiner. Weaknesses - I think the class discussions got a little repetitive at times. Also, class was really long - almost 4 hours on zoom! I think we could have shortened it some weeks.

The strengths of this class were the workshops on interviewing and critiques of small shooting and editing assignments. Producing a short documentary was also a great exercise in nonfiction storytelling. The weaknesses are that the length of the seminar is difficult over zoom. I think we also could've done more in-depth training on Premiere Pro during class time.
This course had few weaknesses I can think of.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual seminar format worked great, especially because we could share pieces easily online.
I think that the size of the seminar allowed for lots of individualized attention and feedback. However, I think the length of the seminar did not translate well to zoom.

More support from the CCAM. I would have liked to have had the option of filming my final with more advanced equipment. But phones worked perfectly fine and I was still able to learn from what materials I had at hand.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES!!! It's such a great opportunity to learn how to make a film. You'll learn so much about documentaries and the filmmaking process. Besides your final project, you will have several really cool creative assignments, e.g. "make a one-minute video about color." so cool!
I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in storytelling, especially storytelling with the potential to create social change.
100 times over I would recommend this course. I absolutely loved taking it and learned so much from Steiner and Mickey Aloisio.
